div.head: Valencia.Â

The Kingdome of Valencia bordereth on the eaÅ¿t Å¿yde vpon the Mediteraneam Å¿ea, & is on all other Å¿ydes enuyroned with other countries of Spaine. The chief citie of this realme is alÅ¿o called Valencia, & of this citie the whole country takerh name. Some authors do witnes it receaued the name of a Kingdome in the year of our Lord 162. There are two principal mountaines in this country , the one called Mariola, the other Penera Golafa, which do produce many Å¿ortes of medicinal herbes, for which cauÅ¿e diuers phiÅ¿itions & apothecaries repaire the-ther for Å¿imples. There is in this country at a place called in the Å¿paniÅ¿h tongue Suriol, a myne of filtter. And in a place called Aioder there are Å¿tones found Å¿tryped with golden vaines. At the promontorie of FiniÅ¿trat are cerraine mynes of iron, though of no abundance. About Segorbie is a quarry out of which marble iu tymes paÅ¿t was taken & Å¿ent to Rome. In Piscene AlabaÅ¿ter is, & in Å¿undry places great Å¿tore of Allum, Red-Ocher, Lyme & Chalk. This country yeildeth fyne wool, which (as in Å¿aid) cometh of the race of cotÅ¿old Å¿heepe tranÅ¿ported out of England into Spaine by licence of King Edvvard the fourth in the Å¿ite year of his raigne. There is great comoditie made in the country by the making of certaine earthen veÅ¿Å¿els which the Spagniards call Pyrocellana.Â This country was long inhabited of the Moores, yntil at laÅ¿t King Iames after a long Å¿iegeThe Siege of Majorca conÅ¿trayned them to leaue the citie of Valencia, out of which there departed at once more than fyfty thowÅ¿and in number, who caried with them all their riches, & left the citie voyd, both of people and welth. There is not (as is thought) any corner of the world Å¿o repleniÅ¿hed with godly gardens, abounding with Å¿uch rare & excellent flowres & herbes, as is this countrie of Valencia.Â Ortelius, Abraham, 1527-1598. An epitome of Ortelius his Theater of the vvorld, vvherein the principal regions of the earth are descrived in smalle mappes. VVith a brief declaration annexed to ech mappe. And donne in more exact manner, then lyke declarations in Latin, French, or other languages. It is also amplyfied with new mappes wanting in the Latin editions. Antwerp: Iohn Norton, 1601. STC 18857.
